@metadata.goal: The student can partition shapes into equal parts

steps.dialogue: Both of these bars are divided into four parts. But one has equal parts and one doesn't. Which bar has equal parts?

prompt.text: Select the bar with equal parts

step.dialogue: Not quite. Look for the bar where all four parts are the same size.

events.name: sections_glow_together
events.description: All four sections of the top bar glow together to show they are equal

events.name: largest_smallest_pulse
events.description: The largest and smallest sections of the bottom bar pulse alternately to show size differences

step.dialogue: [event:sections_glow_together][event:largest_smallest_pulse]Let's think about this together. Equal parts means all sections have the same width. Look closely at each bar to see which one has matching sections.

events.name: measure_sections_equal
events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement lines confirming all sections are equal width in the top bar

events.name: measure_sections_unequal
events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement lines highlighting size differences in the bottom bar

step.dialogue: [event:measure_sections_equal][event:measure_sections_unequal]This can be tricky, so let's work through it together. Equal parts means every section is exactly the same size. The top bar has four parts that are all the same width. The bottom bar has four parts, but they're different sizes - some are wider, some are narrower. That's how we know the top bar has equal parts.

on_correct.dialogue: You identified the bar with equal parts.

@metadata.goal: The student can recognize and identify equal versus unequal parts

steps.dialogue: Sophia cut a paper strip into parts. Are all the pieces the same size?

step.dialogue: Look closely at each piece. Are they all the same size?

events.name: pulse_sections_sequentially
events.description: Each section of bar_1 pulses sequentially from left to right to draw attention to size differences

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_sections_sequentially]Let's think about this together. Compare the pieces carefully - do they look exactly the same width?

events.name: measure_sections_unequal
events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement lines on each section, highlighting the width differences between smallest and largest pieces

step.dialogue: [event:measure_sections_unequal]This can be tricky, so let's look together. Watch as I measure each piece. See how some are wider and some are narrower? When pieces are different sizes, they're not equal. That's why the answer is no - these pieces aren't all the same size.

on_correct.dialogue: You saw that the parts aren't the same size.

@metadata.goal: The student can compare sizes of unit fractions

steps.dialogue: Two chocolate bars are shared equally. Which bar has the bigger shaded part?

prompt.text: Select the bar with the bigger shaded part

step.dialogue: Not quite. Compare the size of one shaded piece in each bar.

events.name: outline_shaded_piece
events.description: The shaded pieces in both bars are outlined to draw attention for comparison

step.dialogue: [event:outline_shaded_piece]Let's think about this together. When a bar is cut into fewer pieces, each piece is bigger. Compare the shaded pieces carefully.

events.name: overlay_shaded_piece_comparison
events.description: Animated overlay showing the shaded piece from bar_halves overlaid on bar_thirds to demonstrate size difference

events.name: measure_piece_size
events.description: Measurement lines appear showing the smaller size of one-third compared to one-half

step.dialogue: [event:overlay_shaded_piece_comparison][event:measure_piece_size]This can be tricky, so let's work through it together. The bar with halves has 2 equal pieces, and the bar with thirds has 3 equal pieces. When we divide the same size bar into fewer pieces, each piece is bigger. So [fraction numerator=1 denominator=2]one half[/fraction] is bigger than [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction]. That's why the bar with halves has the bigger shaded part.

on_correct.dialogue: You compared the unit fractions and found the larger piece.

steps.dialogue: Two pizza strips, each with one piece shaded. Which strip has the bigger shaded piece?

prompt.text: Select the bar with the bigger shaded part

step.dialogue: Not quite. Compare the size of the shaded pieces in each bar.

events.name: outline_shaded_piece
events.description: Outlines appear around the shaded pieces in both bars for comparison

step.dialogue: [event:outline_shaded_piece]Let's think about this together. When a bar is cut into more pieces, each piece gets smaller. Look at the shaded pieces side by side.

events.name: extract_and_compare_shaded
events.description: Shaded pieces from both bars are extracted and positioned side by side, showing the fourth is larger than the sixth

events.name: highlight_correct_answer
events.description: The top bar (fourths) pulses to indicate it is the correct answer

step.dialogue: [event:extract_and_compare_shaded][event:highlight_correct_answer]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. The top bar is divided into 4 equal parts, so each piece is [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction]. The bottom bar is divided into 6 equal parts, so each piece is [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction]. When we divide the same whole into more pieces, each piece gets smaller. That means [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction] is bigger than [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction]. See how the shaded piece in the top bar takes up more space?

on_correct.dialogue: You identified that [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction] is bigger than [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction].

step.dialogue: [event:outline_single_piece]Let's think about this together. When you split something into fewer pieces, each piece gets bigger. Look at one piece from each bar.

events.name: measure_single_section
events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement lines on one piece from each bar, displaying their widths

events.name: comparison_highlight

step.dialogue: [event:measure_single_section][event:comparison_highlight]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. The top sandwich is split into 2 pieces - those are halves. The bottom sandwich is split into 4 pieces - those are fourths. When we divide into fewer pieces, each piece is bigger. So halves are bigger than fourths. That's why fewer pieces means bigger shares.

on_correct.dialogue: You identified that halves are bigger than fourths.

step.dialogue: [event:measure_sections_unequal]Let's think about this together. For a fraction like [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction], all three parts must be the same size. Look at the parts in this bar.

events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement lines with labels indicating the different widths of each section (smallest, largest, medium)

events.name: overlay_equal_comparison
events.description: Overlay showing what equal thirds would look like compared to the current unequal divisions

step.dialogue: [event:measure_sections_unequal][event:overlay_equal_comparison]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. For something to be [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction], we need 3 equal parts. Look at this bar - the parts are different sizes. The first part is smaller, the middle is bigger, and the last is medium. Since the parts aren't equal, the shaded part can't be [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction]. That's why all three parts need to be equal for thirds.

on_correct.dialogue: You identified that fractions need equal parts.
